has been shared online and now even experts admit the mythical beast could be real. In the clip, filmed in Georgia, US, a huge ape-like creature can be seen lurking behind some trees, while the witness films from some distance away.The beast then stands - revealing that it is impressively tall, although in the shaky footage it is hard to tell exactly how big the animal is, as the Daily Star reports.The footage has been widely shared on social media and people are convinced it is a genuine Bigfoot sighting, and even experts seem to agree.  What do you think, is Bigfoot real  Let us know in the comments... The video was shared on Instagram by the account @cryptiduniversity which regularly uploads clips of mysterious creatures.One viewer said: Best footage Iaposve seen in a while - that thing was huge. He said: The subject seems to be very large but the movement possibly gives away the potential for some trickery. The subject seems to be looking down at the ground as it turns indicating it might be a person in a suit who is having some dficulty judging the forest floor beneath them. It makes me think this is more than likely a hoax.  The filmmaker, whose latest documentary On The Trail of Bigfoot is now available on Amazon, added: The thing does appear to be large though, so maybe it’s real  These videos always leave us with more questions than answers.Legends of Bigfoot in the US gained momentum in  when loggers found a giant footprint in Bluff Creek, Calornia, and it became a national news story. Conspiracy theorists think there might be other hidden creatures, known as cryptids, lurking in the wilds, and among these legends are dogman, mothman, the yeti, and even Nessie the Loch Ness Monster.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. title: im strict vegetarian give myself
story: Im a strict vegetarian but I give myself a day off to scoff pigs in blanketsIve been veggie for four whole years... but theres something about that sublime salty meatiness that calls to me each Christmas, writes Elizabeth HaighEvery year I swear blind this will be the year I finally master my addiction. But every year I fail Image: Elizabeth HaighopinionByElizabeth Haigh:,  Dec | commentsI have a confession to make. I’m a vegetarian. But I’m also a pigs in blankets addict. It’s pm on Christmas Day. You can picture the scene: the light is fading, the selection box has been emptied, the dinner plates cleaned. The argument over whether to watch Home Alone or How The Grinch Stole Christmas has finally been settled without injury, thank goodness, and Jim Carrey can sigh in relief that the number one Christmas film of all time has, again, won out. As my family gathers round the screen, exhausted, I’m putting the last of the clean dishes away and covering up the leftovers. I glance furtively towards the open living room door. Not a peep. I tiptoe to the stairs, head cocked like a spaniel, to checkany stragglers are ing from the bathroom after one too many glasses of festive spirit. Nothing. The meat leftovers from Christmas Dinner are sitting on the turkey dish, the only one left uncovered. Five perfect, neatly wrapped, rather smug-looking sausages line the side of the plate, each cuddled up in its own bacon blanket. They’re practically calling my name. I shouldn’t. I definitely shouldn’t. That third mince pie was already a huge mistake: there’s only a certain amount of food a human can take before exploding, right  Quick as a flash, my fingers dart out uncontrollably. One, two, three, enter my mouth one after the other.Are you a bad vegetarian  Tell us about your slip-ups in the comments below Oh, that sublime saltiness! My taste buds sing in gratitude as I noisily foil the plate to cover up the sounds of chewing. “What are you doing in there ” calls my Dad. When I was a child, on Christmas morning he was the guard dog of the kitchen. The only thing stopping my brother and I from gobbling those delicious morsels straight out of the oven. My heart starts racing. I can feel my palms sweating. “Nothing!” I say, quickly. Too quickly. I curse myself under my breath: you almost got away with it. Why are you flushing like a five-year-old who’s been caught drawing on the wall  You’re , for goodness sake. “Are you sure ” “Yes! Just coming now.” I place the last plate inside the already crammed fridge and head into the living room, swallowing the last of the final sausage. Heads turn as I enter, and I smile. “Sorry, just had some trouble with the kitchen foil,” I lie, fairly convincingly. They nod and look back at the screen. Victory is mine!  No part of the Christmas feasting tempts me after four years of meat sobriety. Except those damned pigs in blankets. Every year I swear blind this will be the year I finally master my addiction. It’s time to go cold turkey. No pigs in blankets for me. But every year, I fail. I find myself creeping around corners, desperate to snaffle a cheeky treat while maintaining my vegetarian badge of honour. And I get away with it. The next morning, someone might scratch their head and exclaim: “I’m sure we had more left than that!” But by that time, I’m long gone, and so are my piggish cravings. title: inside 160 year old abandoned
story: Inside -year-old abandoned mansion left after owner tragically died in explosionFormer owner, Lady Cochrane Sursock, died in hospital but the luxury residence is still a part of its namesake’s family who are committed to restoring itThe interior of the mansion showing signs of damage from the explosion Image: Jam Press Roman RobroekBySarah BakerGraeme Murray:,  Dec | commentsA glimpse has been given behind the doors of a -year-old abandoned mansion after its owner died in an explosion. A photographer explored Sursock Palace, one of the last remaining residences of the Lebanese Ottoman-era which is directly in line with the disaster site. Former owner, Lady Cochrane Sursock, was inside the luxury residence during the Port of Beruit explosion but died in hospital sometime later. Despite being built in the s, the luxury residence is still a part of its namesake’s family who are committed to restoring it. A reconstruction plan for the property is expected to take six years and cost an estimated €million Roman Robroek, , a full-time photographer from the Netherlands, was able to get inside the palace to capture not only the damage, but some of the impressive surviving features as well. He said: “Photographing Sursock Palace was part of a project I was shooting for The Heritage Management Organization last summer, where I was covering the impact of the blast that happened in the Port of Beirut in August  on the architecture and cultural heritage in the city. “For this project, we partnered with a local NGO called Silat for culture.  The lovely people of Silat for culture took care of my daily schedule, driving and arranging all the required permissions to enter the locations in the city. A lot of work was involved. “The owner of the palace, Roderick Cochrane, was kind enough to open the doors of his palace for me to photograph the damage caused by the blast.” In addition to art pieces, paintings, books and china, rooms directly facing the harbour where the explosion happened were most damaged. Roman said: “Trust me, the harbour is really close to the palace. All of the glass was shattered and much of the indoor stucco was damaged “The amount of damage I encountered was a big surprise to me. It was tough to see the impact of the blast on the architecture and state of the building. There was so much debris and valuable items were damaged.”  The extent of the destruction can be seen in the once intricately decorated ceiling, which has now been replaced with a temporary metal roof to weatherproof the site and prevent further damage. In hopes of structurally preserving the building, the exterior is clad in scaffolding and netting. Inside, ornate walls and exposed beams are being supported with multiple metal structures. The former grandeur of the palace is still detectable in certain rooms. The elaborate golden front door, stone pillars and arched windows are just a few of the impressive features.  Roman added: “The main and double staircase of the building is one of the features that stood out to me. The craftsmanship in the ironwork and the chandelier are stunning.” The building and its contents were never insured resulting in ious international organisations, university students and other parties stepping in to offer extra support to save its historic grandeur.  The palaceaposs origin goes back to Constantinople and the Sursocks have been recorded as living in Beirut since . The owneraposs wealth is said to have came from in the early th century primarly in agriculture and later in manufacturingAccording to its website, the Sursock empire extended from Mersine, Turkey to Alexandria, Egypt passing by Lebanon, Cyprus and Palestine. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. title: red star stung late in exciting league match
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.RJD-sponsored Red Star welcomed Baljaffray to the Joint Campus G pitch last Saturday where the sides played out a thrilling three-all draw in a match which swung in either direction in horrendous conditions.The sides exchanged goals in the first half, with Stuart MacLean reacting quickest in the box after the Baljaffray keeper couldn’t hold a Fraser Talbot shot and the striker scored to net his eleventh goal in eight games.Baljaffray forced a succession of corners near the end of the half and were on level terms when Red Star were only able to partially clear a corner which fell to the away side’s full back and his shot via the aid of a deflection went past young Leon Murphy in the Star goal. -Into the second half and Star could have retaken the lead when Aaron Moore latched onto a drilled cross from strike partner Stuart MacLean, however, his effort was blocked by an excellent save from the Baljaffray number one.The visitors took the lead after  minutes when a cross caused confusion in the Star defence and the Baljaffray forward had the simple task of finishing into an empty net from close range.Star huffed and puffed for an equaliser, however, they were frustrated by excellent goalkeeping until the goal came in fortuitous circumstances after a long ball was nodded past his own keeper by the Baljaffray centre back meaning the sides were level with  minutes to go.Star took the lead with five minutes remaining when Aaron Moore was able to burst clear of the Baljaffray backline and finish well into the far corner to make it -.This should have been enough to see Star over the line but Baljaffray scrambled a late equaliser when Star again failed to clear a free kick and the ball was bundled over the line to see the match end -.Lochgilphead Red Star are on their travels on Saturday November  when they face their toughest test of the season so far as they take on league leaders and title favourites Arthurlie.

story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Maybe it is a sign that the young folk causing damage at Blarbuie Woodland are maturing, but it was good to hear that some, at least, had gone back to help clean up their mess.Whatever their motivation, good on them.The night-time antics there over quite a period have been pointless, infantile and regularly dangerous. title: co op defends argyll and bute pricing policy
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowIt is central to many rural communities, but the Co-op has faced recent criticism of its pricing and stocking policy in Argyll.What the Co-op does have in its favour is excellent local staff in these stores, but the cost and iety of goods has been questioned # something beyond the control of store staff.Peter Bates, deputy convenor of Tarbert and Skipness Community Council, has taken up the cause after noticing substantial dferences in the price among a iety of goods between Oban supermarkets and the Tarbert Co-op branch.On November  he wrote on the #All Things Tarbert# Facebook page: #The Co-op board and executive really need to have a hard think about their pricing policy, stocking policy and supply issues.#The price dferences between shops in Oban and the Co-op was made startlingly aware to me on our last shopping trip:#Honeydew melon # Oban £., Tarbert £.#Tarbert Co-op has destocked several items over the past year, but they are readily available on the Lochgilphead Co-op shelves. It is not #green# to have to do a -mile car journey for essentials.#The Co-op also seems to be replacing many branded items with their own products which are nowhere near as good.#He believes this policy is #pricing out rural living#, and continued: #It is particularly hard-hitting for those less mobile, non-car owners and the elderly.#Come on Co-op, a change needs to happen.#His post attracted a big response # with people in other parts of Argyll and Bute supporting his views.Mr Bates has since written directly to the Co-op, but emphasised: #The excellent hard-working management and staff at the Co-op in Tarbert are a big part of our community and are very helpful and kind. They have no control over pricing and stocking policy, which is decided by the board.#Stressing that the supermarket operates a UK pricing policy, a Co-op spokesperson said: #Co-op is committed to serving and supporting its rural communities, conveniently, including areas where other retailers often do not trade due to the increased operational costs.#Like all retailers, Co-op has experienced some patchy disruption to the availability of some products, and it is working with suppliers to re-stock as quickly as possible.#Alongside well-known brands, Co-op#s award-winning own-brand products provide shoppers with choice # delivering quality and value, while also enabling customers and community causes to unlock additional value and benefits through its membership programme.#Mr Bates added: #The Co-op bosses in Manchester need to realise that the Tarbert Co-op and others in rural locations are not convenience stores. These are often the only store for miles and are therefore leline stores.#If they do not understand this, then they do not understand the communities they are serving.#Speaking on Wednesday this week, Mr Bates said he had received no reply from Co-op management.He said ##apart from an automated receipt reply, I have heard nothing further. I intend to send the e-mails again.#PIC:Co-op acknowledged #patchy disruption to the availability of some products# but said Argyll store pricing policy is the same as across the UK. _acoopemptyshelvest-co-op-logo-no

title: scotland-women-head-dubai-february-cup-qualifiers
story: THE WOMENS edition of the Rugby World Cup  Final Qualication Tournament will take place on  and  February  at The Sevens Stadium in Dubai.Scotland will compete alongside Samoa, Colombia and the winner of the Hong Kong v Kazakhstan playoff for the last remaining place at Rugby World Cup  in New Zealand, now due to take place between  Octoberndash November, .The Final Qualication Tournament will operate in a semi-final, final format over two match days.This is the first time the womenrsquos edition of Rugby World Cup has featured a Final Qualication Tournament offering teams a second pathway to qualy for RWC  with the winner booking their place in Pool A alongside hosts New Zealand, Australia and Wales next year.Eleven teams have already booked their place at Rugby World Cup , including New Zealand, England, France, Canada, USA, Australia and Wales, who qualied through their final ranking at Ireland , and South Africa, Fiji, Italy and Japan who qualied through their regions.Rugby World Cup  Tournament Director, Alison Hughes, said: ldquoWe are pleased to be able to share the details of the Rugby World Cup  Final Qualication Tournament. A first for a womenrsquos edition of a Rugby World Cup the tournament offers teams a second opportunity to qualy for the pinnacle event and we anticipate a thrilling contest between competing teams in Dubai in February.Tom Burwell, The Sevens Stadium General Manager, said, ldquoWe are hugely excited to host world-class womenrsquos XVs rugby at The Sevens Stadium. It will be the first time such a competition has taken place in the UAE. With the Emirates Dubai s ing over the next two weekends, itrsquos an exciting time for rugby in the region. We are honoured to be working with World Rugby once more in delivering international rugby. With the winner going onto New Zealand and RWC , we are excited to be part of a nationrsquos journey to the very top of the womenrsquos game..removeThe RWC  Final Qualication Tournament will be live streamed across World Rugby and RWC  digital and social s.Rugby World Cup  will be the showpiece event in womenrsquos rugby union s, with the first tickets for Rugby World Cup  selling out in minutes. Tournament organisers are calling on fans to secure their tickets early to avoid disappointment.

title: work-start-soon-gala-fairydean-rovers-stand
story: GALA Fairydean Rovers hope to reopen their iconic Netherdale Stand for the start of next season.The Peter Womersley designed building has been closed since winter  due to public health and safety concerns associated with spalling concrete.A structural assessment was initially conducted in  highlighting the required repairs needed to the stand.Concrete Repairs Limitedhas been appointed to carry out a range of improvements to the category A listed building. The work includes concrete repairs to the stand and turnstiles, drainage improvements and aesthetic enhancements around the stand to restore some of its original features.The work will be funded by Scottish Borders Council within this yearrsquos capital budget along with a contribution from the Gala Fairydean Rovers Football Community Trust.Councillor Gordon Edgar, executive member for roads and infrastructure, said: ldquoAnyone who is familiar with the town of Galashiels will recognise the iconic architecture of the Netherdale Stand and its importance to the town.ldquoIrsquom extremely excited to see work on repairing the building to its former glory progress with the appointment of an experienced contractor.ldquoEnsuring its long-term future by carrying out these necessary refurbishments will allow future generations to benefit from it andthe stand to its former glory.Murray Souter, regional director for Scotland at Concrete Repairs Limited, said: ldquoConcrete Repairs Limited are delighted to be entrusted with the refurbishment of this iconic structure and our team are looking forward to spending the spring and summer months of  in Galashiels working.ldquoTogether with Scottish Borders Council and their design team, we willthe stand to its original glory, looking great, structurally sound, and ready to cope with a full complement of excited Gala Fairydean Rovers fans.The news was also welcomed by Ross Buchan, chairman of Gala Fairydean Rovers Community Trust..removeHe said: ldquoThe stand repair project has been a long journey which began for us in October . The stand is part of our architectural and historic heritage and itrsquos listing places a duty on us, the community, to preserve the structure for future generations.ldquoWe have now reached a signicant stage on this journey, where, Scottish Borders Council have appointed of the principal contractor to carry out the works. We welcome Concrete Repairs Limitedonto the project and look forward to working in cooperation and partnership with them also.ldquoIt will be a day to celebrate when the stand is opened to the public, club and community where we can once again make full use of this very important facility.ldquoThe project has benefitted from working in cooperation and partnership with Scottish Borders Council, Historic Environment Scotland, Fallago Environmental Fund, Live Borders, Gala Fairydean Rovers Football Club, Gala Fairydean Rovers Football Club Community Trust and our very experienced design team.

title: rugby-fans-treat-weekend
story: A feast of live rugby is taking place in the Borders this weekend.There will be a huge Borders derby on Saturday when Hawick make the short trip up the A to Philiphaugh where they will face Selkirk in the Premiership. Elsewhere Jed-Forest head west to meet Glasgow Hawks.In the National League Division One Biggar host Stirling Wolves, Gala face Ayr at Netherdale, Kelso make the long trip to Inverness to face Highland and Melrose host Boroughmuir at the Greenyards.In the National League Division Two Peebles host Kirkcaldy at the Gytes.In the National League Division Three Berwick are at home to Murrayfield Wanderers.In the National East League One Duns are in the capital to face Broughton.In the National East League Two Hawick Linden are away to Leith.In the National East League Three Earlston host Edinburgh Northern.In the Reserve East League One Selkirk A face Hawick Force and Jed-Forest A face Stewartrsquos Melville in Edinburgh.In the Reserve East League Two Peebles Reds are away to Edinburgh Accies, Kelso Sharks host Gala A in a Borders derby and Melrose Storm are in East Lothian to face Preston Lodge A.On Sunday Kelso Ladies are away to Annan Ladies.Elsewhere Hawickrsquos Lisa Thomson and former Melrose player Ross McCann will feature for Team GB Womenrsquos and Menrsquos s teams in the Dubai Sevens. The group stages will be held on Saturday with the latter stages and finals on Sunday.As always check before you travel to make sure that the game is on.A round up of the results will be available on the Borderand Peeblesshire News at noon on Sunday.

title: 900-keep-safe-places-available-scotland
story: TODAYis International Day of Persons with Disabilities and Police Scotland say that they aim to ensure that people with disabilities or long-term conditions, both visible and hidden, are able to access their police service when they need it.Previously people with disabilities have told officers that they sometimes feel less safe where they live.In response Police Scotland say that they are working with local communities to create Keep Safe places for anyone feeling vulnerable when out in the community. There are currently over  across Scotland and the network continues to grow.Officers also say that taking part in the lsquoYour Police Surveyrsquo is one way for people to express their views and needs.Responses to Your Police Survey helps officers identy and eliminate obstacles and barriers for anyone who needs them and they would encourage everyone to take part to influence policing in their area.Your Police Survey is available in easy read and British Sign Language formats.Take part here http:ow.ly BXwHPh

title: massive-game-ahead-vale-leithen
story: VALE of Leithento Lowland League action on Saturday with a trip to face in-form Stirling University.And manager Grant Sandison believes thathis players continue with the same form that they displayed in their last two league games then they are more than capable of causing problems for the students.Vale have not played a competitive game since November  due to having been eliminated in the early stages of the South Challenge Cup and the Scottish Cup.During that break Sandison has been completing his UEFA B Licence Course at the Oriam in Edinburgh and he managed to arrange a couple of friendlies to keep the squad ticking over.Last week Vale lost - to Peebles Rovers and on Tuesday a match against Preston Athletic was abandoned due to adverse weather.Stirling have been in a good run of form recently beating Gala Fairydean Rovers - at Netherdale in the South Challenge Cup."When I first took over, they were down the bottom of the table along with Gretna and Edinburgh University," Sandison said. ldquoBut they have picked up lately and are showing consistency. They are in a good run of form and have done well, taking eight points from their last four games and are in a  position in the table.ldquoI watched them against East Stirling and had them watched against Gala so we are well briefed and I know they have some good young players but I believe thatwe can take the level of performance we showed against Bonnyrigg and Spartans then we can cause them problems.ldquoWe have a couple of things in the pipeline including a possible loan signing and hopefully it will happen before Saturday.

title: galashiels-great-tapestry-ticket-sale-figures-really-good
story: FIGURES around the number of tickets sold for the Great Tapestry centre have been described as ldquoreally good.The visitor attraction, which opened in Galashiels in August, was discussed at a full council meeting on Thursday, November .During the open questions section of the virtual gathering, Galashiels councillor Harry Scott asked how many paying customers have visited and how much revenue had been made.Responding, fellow Galashiels councillor Euan Jardine, of the Conservatives, said that , tickets have been bought, with pound, generated since its opening to the public.According to Mr Jardine, those numbers are ldquoin line with the revised business case projections made in February which included coronavirus implications on visitor numbers.Mr Scott, an independent representative, said: ldquoThatrsquos quite gratying. In these dficult times those figures are very good.ldquoI look forward to the facility enjoying better times ahead.Ahead of the centre opening, the council said it would ldquoattract over , visitors to Galashiels each year ndash creating  jobs and almost pound, of extra spending per annum.

title: electric-vehicle-charging-points-borders-report-recommend-fee
story: OWNERS of electric vehicles in the Borders could soon have to pay to charge their vehicle, it has been revealed.Selkirkshire councillor Gordon Edgar, the councilrsquos executive member for infrastructure, travel and transport, told a meeting last week that an upcoming report will recommend the local authority charges for the service.The plans could be put to elected officials as early as January, according to Mr Edgar.Responding to an open question from Hawick representative Davie Paterson on the issue, the independent councillor said: ldquoA condition of earlier Transport Scotland grant funding for electric vehicle charging points was that they were free at the point to encourage the uptake of electric vehicles.ldquoThis condition has now been removed and Scottish Borders Council, like other local authorities, should be considering introducing a charging regime.He added: ldquoA report on the issue is currently being prepared and will recommend that the council introduces a charging regime going forward.Mr Edgar told the meeting that the total cost to the council for the charging points last year was pound,.Meanwhile, Borders MP John Lamont says that an out of order charging point at Tweedbank Railway Station is ldquonot helping people in the Borders use electric vehicles.Figures from the Department for Transport show that there are a total of  electric vehicle charging devices available for public use in the region.But Mr Lamont, Conservative MP for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk, says the station charger has been out of action for two months.ldquoI am keen to see electric vehicle use become more practical for people in the Scottish Borders, he said. ldquoHowever, cases like the broken charging point at Tweedbank Station are not helping.ldquoWe need to make sure we have a fully-ing electric vehicle charging network. That is why I have written to Scottish Borders Council to try and get the charging point fixed as quickly as possible..removeldquoAs we continue to increase the number of EV charging points here in the Borders, we must ensure that they are well maintained.The Borders is set to benefit from pound, of UK Government funding to support the development of electric vehicle charging points, according to Mr Lamont.On the funding, he said: ldquoI am very pleased that almost pound, of funding will go towards the expansion of our EV charging point network as part of the UKrsquos community renewal fund.ldquoI also appreciate that Scottish Borders Council will be taking on the responsibility of looking after them.

title: peebles-high-quality-path-network-plans-lodged-council
story: PEEBLES could be set for a number of ldquohigh quality walking trails after plans were filed with the council.Proposals to improve the current network while also creating new paths are outlined in an application prepared by Laurence Gould Partnership Ltd at the request of Benson Wemyss Farms.The current situation in the area to the west of the town is ldquonot ideal, providing an opportunity to link to other routes and improve ldquothe overall quality of the local path network.ldquoThe farm is a strong supporter of hillwalking and public access, having set up the highly successful Tweed Walk in partnership with Border Council [Scottish Borders Council], and has applied to the Agri-Environment  Climate Scheme for grant aid in order to improve public access across the farm, providing improved links and connectivity, improved path conditions and accessible paths for all, a report submitted as part of the application reads.ldquoThe farm has a number of existing footpaths that will be improved via the scheme, but the scheme will also create a number of new footpaths for users to enjoy.ldquoPeebles is rapidly becoming a destination for enjoying the outdoors and the woods around Neidpath are increasingly used as an important asset by the community.The business is proposing to ldquoincrease the value of the path network to the local community.According to the report, the new routes proposed include linking two core paths through the Jedderfield Plantation.On that plan, the papers state: ldquoThere are a vast range of heavily used paths through these woodlands that turn to mush during the winter. This project aims to make them accessible for more people throughout the year.A new path from the southwest section of South Park Wood along the edge of the River Tweed to the Old Manor Bridge is also outlined.Existing pathways to be upgraded are located throughout South Park Wood and alongside the River Tweed, along the old Symington, Biggar, and Broughton Railway line, according to the report..removeThe business farms at Edston Farm, located immediately to the west of Peebles.Holiday lets, a horse livery and a wedding venue are currently operated by the business, the papers state.

title: borders-gift-card-proposed-help-boost-high-streets
story: PLANS for a gt card that allows you to spend money at local businesses will be discussed by senior councillors on Tuesday .The national initiative is designed to help local retailers and high streets, according to papers put to the executive committee before next weekrsquos meeting.People can choose the amount of money to load onto the gt card and spend it within businesses that have signed up to the scheme, according to Scottish Borders Council .The view from the council is that the Scotland Loves Local Gt Card initiative would be ldquoworth trying considering the dficulties businesses have experienced during the COVID- pandemic.ldquoThe idea behind the gt card is to try and encourage people to spend money in the local community, thereby helping to support local businesses and the local supply chain, the report states. ldquoLike any other gt card, you can choose the amount of money to load onto the card.ldquoHowever, the key dference in this case is that the money can only be spent within the boundaries of the Scottish Borders and with businesses that have signed up to the scheme.ldquoThe gt cards will feature a -digit MasterCard number, CVV and expiry date allowing them to be used online at independent and national retailers alike, as long as the retailer has a physical presence in the local authority area and is making a contribution to the local economy.It adds: ldquoOur understanding is that neighbouring local authorities such as Dumfries and Galloway and Midlothian councils have already signed up to the scheme and East Lothian Council already had a gt card scheme in place which they believe to be worthwhile.If approved, it will cost the council around pound, annually to market and promote the scheme, according to the papers.It is proposed that SBC trials the scheme ldquoover the short to medium term.A review of the scheme will be undertaken after a full year of operation to help gauge the success of the project, with the results then presented to elected members. The gt card project was launched in July by Scotlandrsquos Towns Partnership.

title: west-linton-host-first-live-coffee-concert

title: winning-return-peebles-burgh-silver-band
story: PEEBLES Burgh Silver Band recently won the th Section of the Borders Entertainment Contest.On November  at The Buccleuch Centre in Langholm, Peebles Burgh Silver Ban joined a number of other Borders bands following the contestrsquos postponement last year due to the coronavirus pandemic.The bandrsquos musical director Peter Holmes prepared the programme which featured Philip Harperrsquos arrangement of Fat Bottom Girlsby Queen, The Road and the Miles to Dundeearranged by Alan Fernie, and I Will Follow Youfrom Sister Act.The band retained the trophy they won at the  competition.At the weekend the band performed at the annual Christmas lights switch-on in Peebles High Street.Peebles Burgh Silver Band now plans to perform on the High Street each Saturday morning throughout December from .am ndash weather permitting ndash and will host a Christmas Concert on Friday, December  in the Burgh Hall.Speaking about these upcoming events, a band spokesperson said: ldquoAll of these are much needed fundraising events for the Band following  months or so of no fundraising.ldquoWe are extremely grateful to sponsors and donors most recently The Provincial Grand Lodge of The Scottish Borders who provided a grant towards Youth Band tuition.ldquoWithout actions like this we would be unable to offer the free tuition and instruments to all.ldquoPBSB will be delighted to see you over the festive period and greatly appreciate all the local support it receives.Members of the Peebles Burgh Youth Band will also perform at the concert. title: weekend-rugby-round-up
story: The weather affected this weekendrsquos rugby card with a number of games postponed and one abandoned.In the Premiership, Hawick won the Borders derby beating Selkirk - at Philiphaugh. title: social-lunches-fun-games-berwickshire-communities
story: BERWICKSHIRE Housing Associationrsquos BeFriend project is joining forces with Abundant Borders to take its Lunch Plus programme to towns and villages across the district.Abundant Borders first started Social Lunches in Coldstream in , with regular visits from BHA BeFriend ndash befrienders, befriendees and staff. Following the success of these weekly events it was decided to take these lunches to other communities across Berwickshire.With support from Berwickshire Alliance, and thanks to Scottish Government Covid Recovery Funding, this is now happening and each Thursday, Lunch Plus pops up in a dferent village! Abundant Borders staff and volunteers prepare homemade soup and sandwiches and BHA BeFriend arrange a iety of games and activities for everyone to enjoy.Karen Birch, Chief Officerat Abundant Borders, said: ldquoThe feedback has been incredible, and it is wonderful to be able to support even our most isolated villages and bring hearty food and good cheer to residents.ldquoItrsquos fantastic to be working so closely with the wonderful folk at BHA BeFriend and to be taking social lunches, fun and games to communities across Berwickshire. It is lovely to see people getting back out into their communities, meeting friends, chatting, enjoying freshly prepared food and having a bit of fun together after the couple of years that we have all had.Terri Bearhope, BeFriend Project Co-ordinator, said: ldquoItrsquos so good to be able to see people out and about again. story: More changes to the Covid travel rules in the UK have been introduced amid concerns surrounding the Omicron iant.Scientists are racing to understand more about the new iant originally identied title: state-pension-correction-exercise-expanded-says-former-minister
story: The scope of a correction exercise putting right state pension underpayments should be expanded, a former pensions minister has said.Sir Steve Webb, a former Liberal Democrat pensions minister who is now a partner at LCP , said several underpayments to orcees had emerged, including some amounting to up to pound,.Sir Steve has written to Peter Schofield, Permanent Secretary at the Department for Work and Pensions .The letter says: ldquoIn your departmental report and accounts for   you set aside around pound billion for repayments to over , people in respect of state pension underpayments.The group already being looked at includes married women and some married men, some people whose spouse had died and and some people aged  or over whose pension was not ldquoupgraded.vw,vw,px, px"Sir Steve Webb has urged the Department for Work and Pensions to lsquotake another look to assess the scale of the problemrsquo The letter continues: ldquoThe purpose of this letter is to ask you to expand the scope of this exercise to include two further groups where I believe there is evidence of administrative error. These are:ldquoWomenwho were orced at pension age but whose pension was not assessed on the basis of their ex-spousersquos contributionsldquoWomenwho orced post pension age and notied DWP of this fact but where their pension was not reassessed on the basis of their ex-spousersquos contributions.Problems with underpayments came to light when Sir Steve, along with This is Money, brought inidual cases to the DWPrsquos attention ndash and Sir Steve said he believed the ldquosystemic problems originally found may also exist for some orced women.The letter says: ldquoIf the Department accepts that a failure to act on a change in circumstances can cause widows and others to be underpaid, why not accept that orced women could be missing out for exactly the same reason .removeSir Steve said growing examples have emerged of orced women who had previously been underpaid due to errors, including:ndash A woman who was orced when she reached pension age was not assessed on the basis of her ex-husbandrsquos contributions. She was underpaid for  years and was recently awarded a back-payment of over pound,ndash Another woman who was orced when she retired and was told she had no state pension entitlement. When she recently made a claim, it was accepted she was entitled to over pound per week and shemade a back-payment of over pound,ndash A woman notied DWP of her post-retirement orce in  but no action was taken. As recently as , she was told her pension was correct. She has now had an increase in her pension of over pound per week plus arrears of pound,ndash And another retiree who orced post-retirement who has received arrears of pound, plus a large pension increase, Sir Steve said.He said: ldquoA series of inidual cases has highlighted blunders which have led to orced women being underpaid by tens of thousands of pounds, in some cases for a decade or more.ldquoThe Department has dismissed concerns around this group far too lightly and should take another look to assess the scale of the problem and then take action to put things right.Sir Steve said copies of the letter had also been sent to the chairs of the Work and Pensions Committee and the Public Accounts Committee, as well as to the head of the National Audit Office.A DWP spokesperson said: ldquoWe encourage people to contact usthey get orced or their civil partnership is dissolved and every year we remind people about doing so alongside the uprating notications we send out.ldquoWe want everyone to claim the benefits to which they may be entitled and we urge anyone of state pension age ndash or their family and friends ndash to checkthey are missing out on financial support.ldquoWe apologise for the errors in the cases identied and have corrected our records and paid the arrears owed..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: State pension correction exercise should be expanded, says former minister

title: bob-dole-lie-state-capitol-nation-honours-senator
story: The body of the late Senator Bob Dole will lie in state in the US Capitol on Thursday as congressional leaders honour the former Republican presidential candidate and World War Two veteran who served in Congress for  years.Mr Dole died Sunday at the age of . He was a leader known for his caustic wit, which he often turned on himself but did not hesitate to turn on others, too.vw,vw,px, px"Bob Dole He shaped tax and foreign policy and worked vigorously to help the disabled, enshrining protections against discrimination in employment, education and public services in the Americans with Disabilities Act.The US Capitol has been considered the most suitable place for the nation to pay final tribute to its most eminent citizens by having their remains lie in state.Mr Dole won the Republican nomination in , but was defeated when President Bill Clinton won a second term. He was also  GOP vice presidential candidate on the losing ticket with President Gerald Ford.Throughout his political career, he carried the mark of war. Charging a German position in northern Italy in , Mr Dole was hit by a shell fragment that crushed two vertebrae and paralysed his arms and legs.The young Army platoon leader spent three years recovering in a hospital and never regained use of his right hand..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Bob Dole to lie in state at Capitol as nation honours senator

title: storm-names-uk-2021-names-including-scottish-island-barra
story: In September every year, the list of storm names is released for the coming -months.These names are ordered alphabeticallyfor example, the first storm of the season will have a name beginning with A, the second with B, the third with C and so on.However, there are only  names on the list which ends at letter W, missing Q and U.The storm year runs from September to September, and only those with the potential to cause an amber or red alert are given a name.Here are all the names for the   year ahead...How are the storm names chosen More than , names were suggested by the public to the Met Office, with many proposals nods to family members who shared traits with storms: "whirlwind" relatives, a "quick as lightning" goalkeeper, a daughter "who leaves a trail of destruction", a cat "who comes in and acts like a strom".A couple of Scottish names have received recognition, including the isle of Barra and the name Logan.The Netherlands and Ireland sharethe list with the UK, meaning some Dutch and Irish names also feature.It markssevenyears of naming storms, whichaims to raise awareness of the potential impact of severe weather events and help people to stay safe and protect themselves and their property before the storm arrives.What are the storm names for   Here are all the names for the   season:ArwenBarraCorrieDudleyEuniceFranklinGladysHermanImaniJackKimLoganMeacuteabhNasimOlwenPoacutelRubySeanTinekeVergilWillemienWhichstorms have we seen so far So faronly Storm Arwen has hit the UK this season, but the it didnt hit lightly.Arriving between Friday November  and Saturday November , Storm Arwen causedwide spread destruction, leading to deaths and leaving homes without power for over a week in some areas.Now, just over a week later, the second storm in the form of Barra is set to batter the country bringing strong winds and heavy snow.

title: covid-scotland-booster-jabs-appear-vaccine-passports-december-9
story: Scotlands deputy first minister confirmed this morning that the Covid booster jab will appear on Scottish vaccine passports for internationaltravel from December .Speaking on Good Morning Scotland, John Swinney said that proof of the booster jab would appear on vaccine passports for international travel from Thursday this week.He added that this would be extended to the domestic vaccine certicationscheme, however this would take slightly longer to implement.When asked whether booster jabs would be included in the vaccine passport scheme, the deputy first minister said: "For international travelit will from  December."And we will expand that for domestic certication but that will take us a little more time to do that. But the critical requirement is for international travel and those changes will be applied from  December."Why is it important that boosters show on vaccine passports To travel to some countries, you must have been fully vaccinated against Covidwithin a certain time limitprior to your visit, which ranges from -days to a year.With Covid jabs rolled out from late last year, it means that some people will already be barred from travelthey cannot provide proof of a booster jab.Proof of a booster jab will therefore help people to meet the vaccination requirements of certain countries.Who can get a booster jab in Scotland All adults in Scotland will be offered a booster vaccine as advised by the JCVI after results showed a third vaccine signicantly improved protection against serious infection.The booster jabs aim to curb a potentialwave of infections caused by the Omicron iant.So far, everyone aged  and over and people who are clinically vulnerable have been invited to book their booster jabs in Scotland.But soon, everyone over the age of  will beable to book a booster jab.These third doses will be offered no less than three months after the second dose of the vaccine was administered..removeThis time frame between second vaccine and booster jab has been cut from six months to three, as advised by the JCVI.

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation

title: tapestry-group-reaching-nationwide-stitchers
story: This follows research carried out by Dr David Caldwell, president of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland, who worked for  years with the National Museums of Scotland.He has studied the list shown that people do show an interest where there is a connection to their own village, estate, family and area.ldquoWe hope that the circulation of the names and places of origin of the fallen will encourage potential stitchers to come forward.Mr Knox said that Colin Beattie, MSP for Midlothian North and Musselburgh, had offered to circulate details amongst colleagues at the Scottish Parliament.Mr Beattie said: ldquoI am delighted to help in this signicant effort and have reached out to my colleagues in Holyrood to ask them to assist using their contacts with local quilting groups.ldquoI am pleased that I have already received several responses and hope that we can establish interest across Scotland to take part in this fantastic project.Designed by Andrew Crummy, the artist behind the Great Tapestry of Scotland and Battle of Prestonpans Tapestry, the Battle of Pinkie Cleugh Tapestry is being worked on by a group of stitchers under the expert guidance of Liz Neilson.Unlike any of Mr Crummyrsquos other tapestries, the Battle of Pinkie Cleugh Tapestry will have up to six huge .Stitchers have been working on smaller embroideries depicting their favourite parts of Musselburgh and what the town means to them.These will be incorporated into the finished , which will be housed at the Brunton Hall.Pinkie Cleugh was the last pitched battle between Scotland and England, fought on September , .It took place during the Rough Wooing, when the armies of Scotland and England fought to determine who should marry the infant Mary, Queen of Scots.The armies were led by the Earl of Arran, Regent of Scotland, and the Lord Protector of England, the Duke of Somerset, whose aim was to secure the betrothal of nine-year-old Prince Edward, the English heir apparent, to five-year-old Mary.There were , Scottish troops massacred in the rout, which became known as lsquoBlack Saturdayrsquo.Historic Environment Scotland is also reviewing the inventory record for the Battle of Pinkie and would welcome comments from the public.The battle was added to the list of nationally important battlefields in Scotland in .A spokesperson for Historic Environment Scotland said: ldquoWe have updated the inventory record for the Battle of Pinkie battlefield site following a request from a member of the public.ldquoThe record has been updated to reflect new research on the historical information and context of the battle.ldquoWe have added dferent interpretations of features connected to the battle and have updated the maps that accompany the record.ldquoThe Battle of Pinkie, which took place in , is thought to be the largest single battle ever fought in Scotland in terms of numbers of combatants.ldquoAs part of our consultation, which runs until Wednesday, December , we are encouraging members of the public to share their views on the proposed updates to the inventory at consultations.his toricenvironment.scot herit age battle-of-pinkieChanges were made to address the reasons why the Duke of Somerset invaded and the wider aims of the  campaign.Updated information regarding armoury and deployment numbers for the English forces has been included.

story: The Clark Community Choir is back in action after the easing of Covid- restrictions and, after performing at Haddington Farmersrsquo Market, Santarsquos Grotto at the Ship Inn in Musselburgh, Seabird Centre in North Berwick, .am-.pm at The Mart, East Linton, .-.pm outside Haddington Corn Exchange, .-pm and at the Ship Inn, Musselburgh, -.pm.Suzanne Walker, a committee member, said: ldquoWe are really excited to be out performing for this year, as we havenrsquot been out since March .During the Covid- lockdown, the choir, led by choir leader Kirsty Robertson, kept up regular practice House was kind enough to let us practise on their front lawn on a Sunday evening so we could socially distance but sing together.ldquoI think we even entertained some of the evening walkers.She added: title: musselburgh-duos-gardening-exploits-see-become-internet-stars
story: Eli Appleby-Donald, , and we KathrynAppleby-Donald, , have created a YouTube channel and website ndash The Kitchen Garden with Eli and Kate ndash aimed at making gardening ldquosimple, easy and fun for everyone.From the garden in the Honest Toun, Eli, a digital teaching specialist at the University of Edinburgh, and Kate, head of collections at the Scottish Parliament, have produced more than  videos which focus on gardening, growing food and flowers.Their YouTube channel now has , subscribers, attracting about , views from  countries.Eli said: ldquoWe had a website and blog that we started back in  when we moved into this house.ldquoAlthough, to be honest, we did it for family to keep them updated and never expected anyone other than our family to read it.ldquoKatersquos mum had been diagnosed with Alzheimerrsquos, so the blog was meant as a way for her to see what we were doing.ldquoWe were really surprised when we started getting messages from folk who had found it and enjoyed it.She said: ldquoWe started making videos to share on the blog, again thinking only a few folk who read the blog would watch them.ldquoBut towards the end of , we started to get a lot more people watching the videos than reading the blog, so I tried to learn a bit more about making videos to make them better.ldquoWhen Covid hit and we all went into lockdown, I really missed being in the classroom but I had been working with students who donrsquot normally delve into the digital world and Irsquod been teaching them to make videos and blog.ldquoI was hearing from them about how much that meant to them to have this outlet while they were locked down and I realised that I was getting something similar from YouTube.Eli said they had done a lot on greenhouse growing because, when they started, they were growing tomatoes and peppers.She added: ldquoI also talk about how to grow from seed to save money because itrsquos a lot cheaper than buying plants.ldquoWersquove done some cooking videos, too ndash things like making passata with the tomatoes yoursquove grown or we did easy sourdough during lockdown.She added: ldquoThe videos are meant as a lsquofriend in the garden with yoursquo idea.ldquoWe only make videos about what we are doing in the garden and specically for growing in Scotland.The couple, who got married in their garden, have covered topics such as mulch, how to sharpen your garden tools, how to get your tomatoes to ripen, how to monitor greenhouse temperatures and composting.Eli said: ldquoIt wasnrsquot until we moved to Musselburgh that I fell in love with gardening.ldquoWhen we bought the house, there werenrsquot really any gardens. The front had been paved over and the back was just a lawn. So, I think we were maybe lucky that we got to design our garden to suit us and start from scratch. It helped fire the passion for gardening, I think.ldquoIrsquove been absolutely astounded at how many amazing folk watch our videos every week. We have had loads of lovely messages from folk saying how much theyrsquove enjoyed learning to garden with us over lockdown and beyond, and how wersquove taken the fear out of it.ldquoThere were even a few messages that made me cry where people have talked about their personal situations and what joy they get from our videos, and how they have made me a part of their weekly ritual.ldquoFolk from all over the world seem to really connect with what we are doing and how we are teaching in our videos, so itrsquos lovely when we get messages telling us what itrsquos been like in their towns and countries, and wersquove made some lovely friends from the US and Canada to Australia, India and even Thailand.ldquoIrsquom so, so glad that folk have found happiness and comfort in our daftness.Catch up with Eli and Kate at youtube c TheKitchenGardenwithEliandKate or thekitchengardenwitheliandkate

title: mary-contini-column-sustainable-christmas
story: We reflect wryly that, often when the immediate present opening is over, it is not unusual to witness the kids distracted with adventures played out with the empty boxes new toys discarded in the corner of the room.I remember the hilarity in our house on Christmas morning in Cockenzie when my brothers, Kevin, Paul, and John Mark, all under  years of age, after an unusually long absence, appeared as Frankenstein and the Incredible Hulk dressed in nothing other than cardboard boxes, toilet paper tubes, red lipstick and black mascara.Their expensive train set, Lego and Fisher-Price garage lay discarded where they had been opened.Those toys have long since been sent to the tip as, I suspect, will many of this yearrsquos toys in the future.Christmas cabins have ed to Haddington town centreDuring the COP climate change conference, very engaged young people were campaigning with great effect to insist governments urgently stop the causes of climate change.They stood with posters and placards frantically shouting for change.They mean it, it is their future after all.The last thing they want are toys which have been transported halfway across the world and made of non-degradable plastic.Fortunately, we have plenty of alternatives on our doorsteps.This year, the Christmas cabins in Haddington are being set up again selling local arts and crafts, gts for all ages and tastes.Cockenzie House is setting up its superb Christmas Fair this weekend, December , as are Stenton and Innerwick communities.Our local high streets are brimming with wonderful independent gt shops fully stocked with locally made treats.We are spoiled for choice. And,you still canrsquot find what you are looking for, an East Lothian Gt Card loaded with lots of money will always be well received.So this Christmas, before you shop, reflect on that toy lsquoelephant in the roomrsquo: it may be made of plastic.

title: tims-tales-fate-thenew
story: It is a famous legend set in post-Roman Celtic times and a version is told in our book East Lothian Folktales, which Mags illustrated.Thenewrsquos father was the legendary King Loth, whom, the story goes, ruled from Dunpelder . Early religious writings tell the story that Thenew was a victim of her fatherrsquos cruel vengeance for what he believed to be her disobedience and wrongful behaviour.One early medieval account by Jocelinus, a monk from Furness, tells us: ldquoBy the kingrsquos command, she was led to the top of a very high hill called Dunpelder, that, cast down from thence, she might be broken limb by limb, or dashed to pieces.But that didnrsquot work, so she was instead taken to the shore of Aberlady and put into the small hide vessel, pulled from the shore and set adrt.Magsrsquo art captures the terror and desperation of Thenewrsquos situation, as her tiny boat is taken by the tide out to the open sea. It is rocked by waves and she clings on for le, the freezing water lapping over her.But thankfully, there is a happy ending to this story. Her small boat begins to drt inland, across the Firth of Forth, away from the kingdom of her abuser and towards the opposite shore, where she lands just in time. There, on the beach by Culross in Fe, she finds a fire with embers still giving warmth.Jocelinus tells us: ldquoThere were, in the neighbourhood, shepherds keeping watch over the flocks. And they beheld a fire lighted close at hand, and coming with haste found the young woman with her childbirth completed, and the child wrapped in rags, lying in the open air. They, moved by pity, took care of them by increasing the fire and supplying food, and procuring other necessarieshellipSt Serf took them in and cared for them, and Thenewrsquos child would become Saint Kentigern.This story is not provable history, of course, more likely itrsquos mostly legend making. Yet unknown truths often lie under the surface of legends and I for one have always seen the universal truths in this story.When I look into the faces of my children, I hope and pray they will never feel the fear and desperation that is on the face of Thenew of being cast at sea with the desperate hope of finding a safe place.And , God forbid, they ever do, I hope they will be met by people like those shepherds.Andever they, or I, were to meet someone in such a desperate situation, then I hope we would be like those shepherds and respond with kindness, understanding and compassion.That, for me, is the truth in this story it may be an ancient tale, but its relevance is undiminished by time.

title: covid-scotland-omicron-isolation-rules-new-covid-variant
story: First discovered in South Africa, Omicron has prompted new restrictions on travelto be introduced around the UK.In England rules on mask wearing have been reimposed -Wales and Scotland have maintainedrules on face coverings throughout the pandemic.In order to try and curb the spread of the new iant, the self isolation rules in Scotland have changed.Heres everything you need to know...Anyone who tests positive forOmicron in Scotland must self isolate for  days.All close contacts of suspected Omicron infections must self isolate for -days, whether they are fully vaccinated or not.People will be told when they receive their PCR resultsthey have the Omicron iant.Anyone who tests positive for Covid- must self-isolate for -days.However, its a dferent story for close contacts.If you are fully vaccinated and a close contact of someone who tests positive for Covid, you must isolate until you get a PCR test.Ifyourresult then comes back negative and youremain asymptomatic, you will no longer have to isolate.Howeveryou are not vaccinated or only partially vaccinated and are identied as a close contact of someone with Covid,you must isolate for -days regardless of the result of your PCR test.

title: msp-hears-opportunities-blindwells-visit
story: Martin Whitfield, a South Scotland MSP, visited the new town of Blindwells on November .More than , homes are being built on the site, between Tranent, Prestonpans and Longniddry, alongside plans for education and healthcare services, retail and leisure facilities.Mr Whitfield, Labourrsquos Shadow Minister for Children and Young People, Lelong Learning and Youth Employment, saw first-hand the opportunities available in construction, as well as the skills needed to help the industryrsquos growth.The former primary school teacher said: ldquoIrsquom pleased to see that Blindwells is now making real progress and helping to create new job and apprenticeship opportunities for young people.ldquoWith hundreds of houses and new public infrastructure being built at the development over the coming years, the site will offer a wide range of ways to build a career in construction.ldquoI welcome these new skilled jobs and look forward to seeing many more local young people forging a career in the industry.More than  new homes are currently being built at Blindwells, which will feature a new school among its amenities, and work is due to start early next year by Persimmon on another  residential properties.In recent weeks, five acres of land have also been launched for exclusive use by businesses seeking new commercial property opportunities in the county.Once complete, the development could see up to , new homes.Iain Slater, development and estates director at Hargreaves Land, the development company behind the Blindwells scheme, said: ldquoAhead of the first residents moving into Blindwells in the weeks ahead, our team has been hard at work applying impeccable standards in building a town that will be a relaxing yet vibrant part of the East Lothian landscape.ldquoIt was an honour for myself and development director Bruce Lindsay to show Mr Whitfield our progress in making a modern and sustainable urban environment in which families and businesses can thrive.

title: parents-speak-terrifying-road-next-two-schools-following-accident
story: Haddington Road has a mph speed limit but anxious parents of children at Law Primary and North Berwick High Schools are calling for the entire stretch to be made mph.A mph stretch begins about four metres before Law Primary Schoolrsquos gate and parents say there are no speed-slowing measures, resulting in cars ldquohurtling down the hill of Haddington Road, picking up speed and then turning the corner to children crossing the road.A recent incident involving an S pupil has ignited further fear for parents in the area.A Police Scotland spokesperson said: ldquoAround .pm on Wednesday, November , officers were called to a report of a -year-old girl struck by a van on the B, North Berwick.ldquoShe was taken to hospital to be checked over, then later released.An East Lothian Council spokesperson added: ldquoWe are aware that a North Berwick High School pupil was involved in a collision with a vehicle near to the junction of Lochbridge Road and Haddington Road on November .ldquoPolice and ambulance were called to attend and the young person was taken to hospital with minor injuries before being discharged.ldquoShe has since ed to school.A concerned parent, who asked to remain anonymous, said: ldquoFamilies are expected to walk down this pavement with cars, buses, lorries hurtling past at at least mph.ldquoThe nature of the road encourages you to pick up speed as it is wide, straight and goes downhill.ldquoThere are no signs about it being a school area until you get right to the school.ldquoThere are no crash barriers along this stretch of road ndash particularly needed at the bottom of the bank as this is where children regularly fall off scooters and bikes into the road as they shoot off the corner after gaining speed coming down the hill ndash literally not nearly a week goes by without us receiving messages of near misses.Another concern from families in the area relates to Covid restrictions, which mean parents are unable to wait in the school playground to collect their children, unless the child is in primary four or below.This has resulted in packed pavements, with people ldquohaving to step onto the main road to make way for prams, bikes, scooters and dogs.One parent said that the issues had been discussed with East Lothian Council, North Berwick Community Council, North Berwick Trust, the school and parent council, but that no solution had been found.They added: ldquoThere has been no movement in years to try to ensure our kids can get to and from school safely.A number of safety measures have been suggested, including a path from the newbuild homes to take children directly into school premises, a crash barrier along the pavement, a crossing from Lochbridge Road across Haddington Road ndash which is currently overseen by a crossing patrol during peak hours ndash or a reduced speed limit to mph as soon as cars enter North Berwick.Additionally, parents are seeking an increase in signage on Haddington Road to alert drivers that they are approaching schools.
